results.title: 'On the wallaby track' by Frederick McCubbin, 1896
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton, Art Gallery of New South Wales and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Australian eye I”.
A study of the painting by Frederick McCubbin, “On the Wallaby Track”. Other major works of McCubbin are examined and the influence upon him of French genre painter Bastien-Lepage is discussed.

results.title: 'Murder ahoy'
results.creator_credit: George Pollock, Lawrence P. Bachmann and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: A sea-going whodunit where the intrepid Miss Marple finds herself investigating events on the HMS Battledore, a navy training ship designed to give young hoodlums a chance at new lives. Miss Marple discovers some-one is training the delinquents to be good thieves instead of good citizens and is willing to kill to keep the fact quiet! Murder Ahoy features a rogues gallery of suspects and ingenious means of despatching victims including strychnine-laced snuff, a poisoned mousetrap and a noose from a yard-arm. Starring Margaret Rutherford, Lionel Jeffries and Stringer Davis.

results.title: 'Mount William from Mount Dryden'...by Eugene Guerard, 1857
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 17 of Series “The Australian eye III”.
Eugene Von Guerard, (affectionately known as ‘the father of the Gallery School’ Victoria, being founder), with his training in the naturalistic German school of Romanticism, was able to produce works that express reverence for nature’s mysterious processes as well as appreciation of the splendours of the untamed Australian landscape. The European concept of sublimity is discussed and some of Von Guerard’s most majestic works are studied.

results.title: 'M' [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Fritz Lang, Seymour Nebenzal and Nero-Film
results.brief_description: Peter Lorre in his greatest role portrays a psychotic child molester - a pathetic vagabond figure who experiences a frenzy at the sight of tender young school girls, and try as he may, he is unable to control the fervour of his criminal inclinations. The police disregard his letters of confession to them as the work of a lunatic, leaving the underworld to take the law into their own hands. The stylised realism of the sets and the detachment with which the opposing forces of law and outlawry are portrayed place this now classic film within the ambit of the so-called ‘new objectivity’ which was a reaction in Germany to the expressionist movement. This version is the longest available.

results.title: 'Lake St Clair' by William Charles Piguenit, 1887
results.creator_credit: David Muir, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Australian eye III”.
A study of the painting “Lake St Clair” (1887), by William Charles Piguenit. Features a brief biographical description of the artist including his life works in terms of his travels and experiences with nature as Australia’s first important landscape painter born in Australia (Hobart, 1836-1914). His first important works began with his series on Lake St Clair. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: 'Justice' of the Red functionaries
results.brief_description: Inspired and colourful narration accompanies this montage of German propaganda designed to illustrate the worst tyrannies of a Soviet State. Shows the administration of justice in 1948 as applied under Ulbricht’s communist regime. Includes pictures taken in Soviet zonal courts, and interviews with judges who fled to the West. An example of cold-war era red-scare demagoguery.

results.title: 'For better, for worse'
results.brief_description: Taking an average viewer as its hero this cartoon demonstrates satirically how television can be a pleasure and a source of information or, if taken in too large a dose, can mesmerize and engulf the viewer. It contains some inventive gags, lively animation and genial humour.
